intro: Archibaccharis simplex, commonly known as the narrowleaf hibiscus, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its narrow, lance-shaped leaves and showy, five-petaled flowers that range in color from white to pink. It typically grows in wetlands and along stream banks, thriving in moist, well-drained soils. The plant is often used in wetland restoration projects due to its ability to stabilize soil and provide habitat for wildlife.
